Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2014 06:38PM writinghelps wrote: I had my sim today. It was a breeze compared to the MRI-guided biopsy i had last March and of course better than the chemo experience. It was actually a nice time to just rest. I am a bit worried about how bad my skin will get. The tape they put on my skin today for the simulation made me red. I asked the RO if he would do a blood draw and check my counts because my muscle fatigue (from chemo) has gotten worse this past week. I can't believe how sore they are. It's like the soreness after an intense workout or hike. And the only thing i've done is get out of the bed in the morning! Anyway, he gave me a lab order, i had it done and my counts look ok. So I guess it's just from the chemo. Wow. Insane Evil Poison.

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2014 11:25AM writinghelps wrote: Hi Cceandme and the Moderators, Good luck on your last chemo Cceandme. I think I am also more nervous about rads than I was with chemo or surgery.  I wonder if it's because we're tender, emotionally and physically, and so very gun shy at this point. I have no idea how many rounds I am having which is sort of unusual for me because I am usually on top of things.  The RO may have told me but I didn't hear it. It may be because I am so worried.  I hope the first few weeks are as uneventful as they promise. I could use the weeks to recover mentally and be ready for the discomfort toward the end. Thanks Moderators for the links. Peace, Wendy
Posts.Title: Fall Rads 2014 writinghelps sas-schatzi

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2013 08:34PM writinghelps wrote: Here is an update: (sorry I haven't been keeping in touch)  I decided to have the lumpectomy and excisional biopsy.  That night the swelling got so bad I had to go back to the ER and the BS had to go in and drain and then inserted a drain (those things are the devil). During the intial surgery she excised me three times in the area of the intial DCIS until she got clean margins. The pathology showed more DCIS, LCIS, ADH & ALH. I sent all my records to Dr. Michael Lagios in California and he recommended I heal for a few months and then have another Mammogram and MRI.  He said based on the Van Nuys Prognostic Index my recurrence rate at a mean 12 years followup is 6.2% without irradiation therapy and 2.5% with irradiation therapy. I am very pleased with these numbers and will take his recommendations. And finally I just stepped over to join the ranks of those who view DCIS as precancer.   A friend in the field has made the comment "It's a precancer that is treated like cancer."  As a cellular biologist myself (and reading a bit about what is going on in the field) I get the impression that in the future DCIS will not be treated so aggressively and the SOP for DCIS will change. I hope it is closer than it seems.
Posts.Title: discombobulated about DCIS writinghelps writinghelps

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2014 01:11PM writinghelps wrote: Hi All, I read here a a lot but don't comment much (I'm actually a regular on the May board although it is much slower than this board so i hang out here more). I wanted to share my experience with pain and the BMX in case anyone wanted the option I was given. I haven't seen anyone mention it yet.. My surgeon inserted a sprinkler-like system under the skin that distributed a lidocaine-like drug over a period of 5 days. It was fantastic! I was trying to avoid the other type of pain meds (because i am a recovering alcoholic/drug user) so the BS and anesthesiologist had a pow wow and decided on this system.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in April 2014 Kazzy115 Sunshine36

So, hello *waving* And I want to send out a BIG thank you for being so open and honest on here. Your experiences have helped me so much.
